Debate on President's Address

(Third allotted day)

Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [17 October 2011],

'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:

"We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' – [Dr Lam Pin Min].

Question again proposed.

Mr Zainal Sapari (Pasir Ris-Punggol) : Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join this debate. I support our President in advocating an inclusive approach in discussing Singapore's future. While we can pride ourselves with having a safe, secure and prosperous Singapore, we cannot ignore the fact that there is still a large segment of our fellow Singaporeans earning low wages. Based on 2011 WIS recipients, it is estimated that we have more than 400,000 workers earning a salary below $1,700.

I have met many low-wage workers through my work with the NTUC, and at Meet-the-People sessions. There are employers that take advantage of their vulnerable position. For example, many cleaners, not only do they earn low salaries, a major component of it will be in the form of reimbursements such as transport, laundry or mobile phone allowances that do not attract CPF payments or included in overtime work calculations. Many struggle to meet the basic needs of their family members, and may not have job security, and may be afraid to speak up for their rights as they may feel worried about losing their jobs, especially if they are older workers. Rising costs have made their daily struggles even harder. Although the Singapore economy has performed well over the years, there is an increasing wealth divide.

Page: 241

We have done much to improve the life of our low-wage workers. Several Members of Parliament yesterday have made several suggestions on what could be done to help needy families or low-wage workers. I fully support their suggestions. While I acknowledge that a lot has been done to help low-wage workers, we can still do more. Recently, it was reported in the papers that the real income growth for low-wage workers for the past 10 years has been flat. Sir, I would like to urge the Government to ensure that the push to increase real wages by 30% in the next 10 years will be felt by low- wage workers as they are the ones who are most in need of higher salaries. In fact, I would like to suggest revising the target for low-wage workers' salaries to increase in real terms by 50% in the next decade so that there will be an even greater impact on these workers.

Last Monday, NTUC together with our tripartite partners reviewed and discussed our efforts to help low-wage workers. NTUC has been championing the Workfare Income Supplement, Workfare Training Scheme, and Inclusive Growth Programme and encouraging companies to embark on "Best Sourcing" instead of "Cheap Sourcing". We do have many success stories to show how these schemes helped boost productivity and led to wage increases for low-wage workers and NTUC fully support such initiatives. Personally, I have two questions. First, are the salary increments given to these more productive workers equivalent to the productivity gains? Second, is the impact from NTUC's efforts alone, widespread enough to make a real difference to the 400,000 low-wage workers out there?

Sir, as a labour MP, I would like to urge that the drive towards achieving sustained real wage growth for low-wage workers be a Key Performance Indicator for every Ministry, Government agency, statutory board and social enterprise. We must do this as a shared national initiative to help our fellow Singaporeans. We cannot afford to have any Ministry or organisation to take a "bo-chap" attitude in ensuring better wages and better working conditions for their workers.

Sir, for a start, every Ministry and Government-related organisation must take ownership of the Inclusive Growth Programme. NTUC has been driving the Inclusive Growth Programme (IGP) to help companies boost their productivity and share the productivity gains with the low-wage workers but, there is an urgent need for this programme to be ramped up quickly for a greater widespread impact. Unless, Government agencies take the lead in implementing IGP, we may not realise the full impact of IGP in helping low-wage workers.

In my conversation with union leaders on the plight of low-wage workers, many have lamented that the strategy of outsourcing manual or blue-collar jobs in many organisations, including Government bodies, has partly contributed to the current situation of depressed wages for these workers. While outsourcing has many benefits – such as saving operational costs, keeping companies economically nimble and allowing them to focus on their core businesses – it has its drawbacks, too. Competition amongst service providers inadvertently leads to cost-cutting and this manifests itself in the form of low salaries for their workers. To make matters worse, contractual obligations spanning a few years at fixed contract price means that the salary of these low-wage workers will stagnate. Sir, we should ask ourselves this question, is it morally justifiable to save cost through outsourcing at the expense of workers' salary?

Sir, I would like our Government Ministries and statutory boards to re-look at the strategy of outsourcing jobs that are needed on a daily basis. I recall when I was a child, my father was a civil servant as he worked as a daily-rated worker with PWD. As a result, my whole family had medical benefits that covered public clinic consultations. We did not have a lot of comforts but our basic needs were met. I wish this can be the case for all low-wage workers working in Government bodies to be direct employees so that they are protected from the bluntness of the economic system.

Sir, I do understand having these workers as direct employees will lead to higher expenditure for Ministries and public institutions, and this seems to go against the principle of exercising prudence in spending public funds. However, we should ask ourselves even if we can quantify the savings made from outsourcing, what is the social cost to it? If we spend more of public funds to have low-wage workers as direct employees of the public sector, while ensuring that they have higher salaries and better benefits, would it not translate to looking after the needs and welfare of Singapore workers? Moreover, having workers as direct employees will increase the worker's sense of belonging to the public service and they will feel that the Government is taking care of their interests.

Sir, if employing these low-wage workers as direct employees is not viable for whatever reasons, I would propose then for Ministries and Government bodies to practise "Best Sourcing" according to its rationale and intent. Based on our sense on the ground, there will be less resistance from the Ministries if the Ministry of Finance reviews the financial compliance guidelines in the Government's Instruction Manual to be more explicitly in supporting "Best Sourcing". NTUC, as the champion for workers, is willing to work with the MOF on this and work with other Ministries on its implementation.

Sir, "Best Sourcing" is not new to NTUC which has been actively championing "Best Sourcing" as an initiative to help low-wage workers earn better salaries and employment terms. This year, the Tripartite Committee on Low-Wage Workers will be pushing for companies to practise "Best Sourcing" so that the basic rights of low-wage workers are protected and they receive fair wages. I support this call and would like to suggest that MOM and NTUC work on a list of good service providers that give fair wages and employment terms to their workers. Ministries and public institutions should then consider only tenders put up by these companies recognised by the unions. Again, NTUC is willing to work with any Ministry to ensure that the workers are being paid a fair salary.

Sir, earlier, I shared that the nature of the contractual obligation between Ministries and the service providers will make it difficult for low-wage workers to get salary increases annually. Let me give an example. Currently, there is a Ministry with a cleaning contract that is a term for three years with a three-year extension and the contract price remains throughout. Workers under this contract will typically have stagnant wages for six years. I think this is totally unacceptable. I would like to encourage Ministries to relook their existing contract with service providers to enable that these workers do enjoy wage increments instead of earning the same salary for the duration of the fixed price contract. This is something that must be done if the Government is serious in helping low-wage workers earn sustainable real wage increases of 30% – or was it 50% – in 10 years.

If all these measures do not sufficiently address the issue, then we might have to think about introducing a law to make service buyers legally accountable for the welfare of these workers. Sir, please allow me to speak in Malay.

(In Malay): [P lease refer to Pg 319-320 for Vernacular Speeches .] The Malay community in Singapore has attained many achievements in education and employment. There are more outstanding students who managed to win awards and many successfully continued their studies to the post-secondary level in the ITEs, polytechnics and universities.

As for employment, there are now more Malay professionals with an increase in the number of graduates having diplomas, bachelor's degrees, Master's degrees and PhDs. These achievements were due to the efforts and the hard work of our community members who contribute to the Malay-Muslim bodies to improve the social situation of the community. But even though these achievements bring pride, our community now faces new issues. I will make an effort to highlight important issues related to the Malay-Muslim community throughout my term as a Member of Parliament. However, for today's Parliament sitting, I will focus on two issues: the issue of low-wage workers, and the issue of drug addiction, which are still affecting segments of our community.

Sir, in my English speech, I spoke about many issues that are faced by low-wage workers in Singapore. This group faces many challenges, and financial problems can be one of the factors causing a cycle of problems for the worker and his family. Some have problems in paying their housing arrears and are forced to rent a flat; some also have problems in their families and in disciplining their children. It is not easy to solve these problems because they need help at many levels, like upgrading the workers' skills, finding ways to enable the workers to get a higher salary, providing support for their children's education, and giving focus to solve the problem of dysfunctional families. Due to the various problems that they face, I have urged the Government and employers to find ways to create the real wage increase of 50% for low-wage workers within the next 10 years. I hope this can materialise.

However, the effort to upgrade the status of workers is not only the job of the Government. Workers also play a big part in this effort. Malay workers must continue to monitor news on the development of the major global economies because if the world dips into recession, it will have an impact on Singapore's economy. If Singapore's economy is affected, it will have an impact on workers and some may be affected and retrenched due to companies closing down. In order to try to avoid this negative impact on us, each worker must find or grab opportunities to upgrade their skills at their workplace. A skilled worker may be able to ride through the impact of an economic recession when it happens. Do not wait until something bad happens before realisation dawns on you. If there is an opportunity, grab it and do not waste it.

Next, the problem of drug addiction. Sir, I have personally seen among my own acquaintances the painful suffering inflicted on the family of a drug addict. It causes many family problems and the ones worst affected are the children of the addict because they have to live without a mother or a father all because of drugs. Sir, much effort has been made to reduce the number of Malay drug addicts. The community will surely remember the good deeds of the late Mr Harun Ghani who worked tirelessly to solve the problem of drug addiction when he was the Political Secretary in the Ministry of Home Affairs. Success was achieved but we must continue to work hard in ensuring that our community members do not fall into the drug trap. This includes ensuring that there is no problem of relapse, especially with the advent of new drugs. As a member of a steering committee on the problem of drug addiction, I hope to be able to work with Malay bodies like Mendaki, Jamiyah and Pertapis and others to further understand this problem and try to solve it together. I hope that the Malay bodies can work hand-in-hand with the Government and relevant agencies like SANA, NCADA and SCORE to eliminate this problem. If it is not prevented effectively, it will result in a vicious cycle because the children of drug addicts may be influenced by the behaviour of their parents and can be trapped by the same problem when they grow up. Therefore, I would like to urge the Malay bodies to work hand-in-hand so that we can find ways together to overcome this problem and ensure that the Malay children do not fall into the drug trap.

(In English): Before I end, Sir, allow me to share my thoughts on Mr Chen Show Mao's views, please. Yesterday, in his maiden speech, Mr Chen shared his views on the importance of investment in human capital. Fundamentally, our Government is and has always been aware of its importance and a substantial amount of investment was made in areas of transport infrastructure, qualities, opportunities in education, healthcare and housing. I was surprised that he opined that Singaporeans have been under-served in recent years in these areas. I have lived and worked in Singapore for 46 years and over the years, undeniably, we have made much improvements and progress in these key areas. While I acknowledge that there are areas for improvement, I would not go to the extent to say Singaporeans have been under-served. In education, for instance, which I have been part of for the past 20 years, I have seen and experienced the transformation of the education service designed to mould the future of the nation. In every undertaking we did, we are constantly guided in providing the best for our children for we believe this would be best for Singapore. Our education system has been acknowledged by many independent international bodies to be among the best in the world. Mr Chen, let me assure you that Singaporeans have not been under-served in terms of investment in education. However, I would like to give Mr Chen the benefit of doubt in his view and look forward to hearing his alternative proposal to better our education system. Sir, I support the motion.

Ms Low Yen Ling (Chua Chu Kang) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank you for the opportunity to rise in support of the motion of thanks to the President for his Address. In the six months that I have been with Bukit Gombak residents, I have met Singaporeans in different circumstances. One common thing binds us all, that is our hope and desire for a better future. We aspire for the best for our children and families. Many of us work hard to improve our lot, like our forefathers. The traits of diligence and determination to realise our aspirations are part of our Singapore DNA. Today, this Singapore "DNA" is being challenged and re-shaped by new forces and changes in the global economy. Technology is also transforming the way we work. There are now higher and more complex demands on education. In my speech, I will cover three broad points:

First, future-proofing PMETs above 40 years old for lifelong employability. Second, strengthening our bilingual advantage. And, finally, identifying the "Invisible Children". I call them "Invisible Children" because these are children not exactly with special needs but with learning difficulties.

Let me first kick off with the first topic of PMETs (Professionals, Managers, Executives and Technicians). Many Members in this House in the past two days have talked about how the nature of employment has been transformed due to rapid globalisation, technology advancement and shorter business cycles. Jobs can now be easily outsourced, "offshored" and even disaggregated into tasks for virtual and temporary or even contract labour. This means that jobs essentially come easily under threat.

The 3 September issue of The Economist highlighted this problem by citing several economists, including Mr Paul Krugman, who argued that post-industrial societies would be characterised not by a relentless rise in demand for the educated but, interestingly, by a great "hollowing out". Smart machines are eroding mid-level jobs. High-level job growth will eventually slow down. The article described how even some jobs in professions like law and medicine are being undermined by computer-search specialists and online medical advice.

In the face of such challenges, there is a growing urgency for us to future-proof our PMETs above 40 years old for lifelong employability. They form a key cornerstone of our workforce. According to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) Labour Report in November 2010, the share of PMETs in our resident workforce grew from 42% in 1999 to 52% in 2010.

The issue of jobs for PMETs over 40 years old was highlighted by several of my residents during my interactions with them in the past six months. Many of them are well educated PMETs above 50 years old, worried about their jobs as well as family and mortgage commitments. Sir, please allow me to read an email extract from one of my residents, whom I will address as Evan.

"Ms Low, I am committed to contribute to the workforce and all I need is a good opportunity from some employers who believe in me. Although I am 50 this year, I am still capable of running 2.4 km under 13 minutes, swim at least 10 laps and have been practising yoga for the past 10 over years. I did all these to be healthy and employable and yet I am now facing the harsh reality of not even securing an interview despite months of job searching."

Evan's story, over the past six months that I interacted with my residents I realise, is not uncommon. In Gombak where we are home to 32 condominium developments, there are many middle-income families with the sole or even joint breadwinners as PMETs. Now, according to MOM's 2010 Redundancy and Re-employment Report indicated that a third of those who were made redundant were PMETs. And of the resident workforce made redundant, 61% were above 40 years old. MOM's recent Labour Market Report for Second Quarter 2011 observed that PMETs and those above 40 had the lowest rate of re-entry into employment. In my opinion, the number of older PMETs who will find it harder to re-enter their existing industry will continue to grow due to industry transformation arising from global competition. Just this month, MOM's Singaporeans in the Workforce Report showed that the employment rate of our population between 55 and 64 years old has fallen behind that of Japan, South Korea and the US.

I sincerely urge the Government to continue to review how we can further future-proof our PMETs above 40 years old for lifelong employability. Currently, we have strong supply-driven training programmes and infrastructure. We have the e2i and CDCs providing help to workers and PMETs, as well as programmes such as STEP (Skills Training for Excellence Programme) and EDGE (Executive Development and Growth for Excellence). In 2011, we will welcome the opening of the two CET (Continuing Education and Training) campuses. I understand $5 billion will go into the Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund. There will be a $150 million fund for PMET training that will train up to 60,000 PMETs.

With this in mind, how can we also catalyse a robust demand for the know-how and skill-sets of these valuable and well-trained PMETs? These supply-driven training programmes and sources of workforce need to be matched by a corresponding demand from employers, be it private or public sector.

Sir, may I suggest three points of action for the Government to consider? First, we can seek to foster greater demand and jobs for PMETs above 40 years old. We need to encourage employers to have a mindset that positively values employees of 40 years old and above. With more people living well into their 80s, 60 has become the new 40. Those above 40 years old offer a wealth of experience, skills, maturity and loyalty – traits that are very much valued by today's employers.

We need leaders in Government, business and education to be creative, to be willing to consider solutions that we have not tried before. The Government can also take the lead to support and encourage employers to desire and value the benefits of employing PMETs above 40 years old.

Take the UK as an example. The UK government's Age Positive campaign seeks to recognise and influence the attitudes and practices of employers and their staff. Its Code of Practice encourages the employers to make decisions about recruitment, training and retention that do not disadvantage someone because of their age.

Secondly, we can also look into practical ways of increasing the pipeline of fulfiling jobs for PMETs above 40 years old. The CET Masterplan aims to equip Singaporean workers with the skill-sets of entering emerging and growth industries. Perhaps, we can complement this by enhancing EDB's Strategic Attachment and Training Programme (STRAT) for PMETs above 40 years old. Those with the interests and skill-sets can be encouraged to move into adjacent growth areas, for example clean energy, identified and promoted by the Government agencies.

Thirdly, PMETs over 40 years old can be an invaluable human resource to help develop a stronger base of globally competitive Singapore enterprises, so as to grow the external wing of our economy. The benefit that PMETs can bring to SMEs, in fact, is illustrated by one of my residents whom I will call Jason. Jason is 53 years old, married with two teenage children. He was a General Manager of a multi-national corporation where he worked for more than 25 years. In March this year, he left the company due to ill health and spent a couple of months looking for a job. I met Jason in June and roped in CDC, WDA and e2i to help him. He went for some networking sessions and just last month, we were all very glad that he was hired to be a Service Manager of a listed local company that is in the marine industry. He now oversees more than 40 engineers and technicians. His company also draws upon his extensive experience to deal with the company's MNC clients.

Sir, I believe we stand a good chance of successfully tapping PMETs for the future growth of our SMEs. We can do more in this area – whether to provide job matching for PMETs above 40 years old to the SMEs, or to help these PMETs gain "T-shaped competencies". With that, they will be able to move into adjacent growth industries more easily when their industry strengths are coupled with a broad knowledge of horizontal strengths such as management, finance or even business operations. This will certainly be very useful in times like these, where we see that the centre of economic gravity is shifting to Asia.

At this point, Sir, please allow me to elaborate how we can further future-proof for Singaporeans by strengthening our bilingual advantage. Please allow me to switch to Mandarin.

(In Mandarin): [Please refer to Pg 321-322 for Vernacular Speeches .] Singapore's bilingual policy created people like us today, and it has also laid the foundation for future development. We all know English is an international language and a must in the global business world. Our bilingual policy in the early years gave us an edge over other Asian countries. We can use Chinese fluently to communicate with entrepreneurs from China and benefit from it. I personally know many entrepreneurs from China. They tell me that they can see the advantage of our bilingual policy that has trained many bilingual talents. We can communicate at ease with various parties in the international arena and have meaningful discussions with them. The rise of China and India and the shift of economic centre to Asia will bring boundless opportunities to this region.

Although Singapore has the bilingual advantage, more countries in the world are realising the importance of being bilingual. People are eagerly learning Chinese or English, and one day they will become bilingual elites too. These people are making fast progress. We cannot ignore these competitors. We should implement more effective education policies to educate the next generation so they can maintain our bilingual advantage. In fact, while studying mother tongue, we can also gain deeper understanding of Chinese cultural values, the root of being Chinese. We must pass on these values to the next generation.

The Singapore Internal Security Act (ISA) has its roots in preventive detention laws introduced by the British colonial government to tackle serious threats to social and political security in Malaya. After Independence, the ISA remained a law in a sovereign Singapore and was important in enabling the Government to continue to counter national security threats to our young nation. The ISA empowers the Government to address threats to national security not just through preventive detention, but also other measures like the imposition of curfews to deal with civil disorder.

While the ISA provides considerable powers to deal with threats to security, it also contains important safeguards which have been enhanced over time. An Advisory Board chaired by a Supreme Court Judge reviews all detentions under the ISA. In 1991, the ISA was amended to give the Elected President veto powers such that where the Advisory Board recommends the release of any person, that person cannot be detained or further detained by the Government without the President's concurrence.

Determining what is a security threat to Singapore that requires the use of the ISA is a judgement. This judgement must be made by the elected Government of the day, at the given time and based on the situation at hand. The ISA allows an overall assessment of the threat posed by a person to be presented and considered in totality, unlike a criminal case that is tried before the courts which consider only specific acts directly related to that charge. The ISA thus allows the Government to act quickly to prevent a threat from developing into something very serious such as a bombing; or to stem an organised pattern of subversion which promotes civil disturbances and disorder.
